data.description: In the early 1900s, paleontologists unearthed the Age of Mammals when they found full skeletons of extinct Miocene mammals in the hills of Nebraska -- species previously only known through fragments. At the same time, an age of friendship began between rancher James Cook and Chief Red Cloud of the Lakota. These two unprecedented events are preserved and protected here... at Agate Fossil Beds.
data.directionsInfo: From US 20: 22 miles south of Harrison, NE on State Hwy 29, then three miles east on River Road (paved) From US 26: 34 miles north of Mitchell, NE on State Hwy 29, then three miles east on River Road (paved). From State Hwy 71: 25 miles west on the unpaved portion of River Road.

operatingHours.description:
The park's two trails are open from dawn till dusk every day.

Visitor Center features Miocene Mammal fossils, a 12 minute movie, and the James H. Cook Collection,  a unique collection of American Indian artifacts that were gifts to James Cook and his family.
operatingHours.name: Trails

images.title: Visitor Center on the Prairie
images.altText: The visitor center sits in the middle of mixed grass prairie.
images.caption: From the Fossil Hills Trail the Visitor Center is a ship in a sea of prairie grasses.

images.title: The Agate Fossil Hills and Tipis
images.altText: Tipis and Fossil Hills represent the two subjects that Agate Fossil Beds interprets.
images.caption: One of the first impressions that visitors have are the tipis and the Fossil Hills.

images.title: A July Storm Passes
images.altText: Thunderheads are common in July.
images.caption: Summer storms include thunderheads and lightning and can be exciting and dangerous.

images.title: Dinohyus in the Visitor Center Fossil Diorama
images.altText: The Dinohyus was a scavenger, nicknamed "Terrible Pig"
images.caption: Visitors stare in wonder at the huge head of the "apex" predator of the plains some 20 million years ago.

images.title: The James H. Cook collection
images.altText: This buckskin shirt decorated with quills was worn by Red Cloud.
images.caption: Visitors agree that this shirt decorated with quillwork and worn by Red Cloud of the Oglala Lakota is a priceless piece of history.

data.weatherInfo: Summers can be very warm, high 90's to 100 with the frequent afternoon thunderstorms. Plan to hike early and come down from the higher points if storms threaten. Winter temperatures can dip as low as -20 with snow and wind. Heaviest snows can be expected in late Spring.
data.name: Agate Fossil Beds

data.description: Follow in the footsteps of over 250,000 emigrants who traveled to the gold fields and rich farmlands of California during the 1840s and 1850s: the greatest mass migration in American history. The California National Historic Trail is over 5,000 miles long and covers portions of 10 states. Step into history along more than 1,000 miles of ruts and traces from travelers and their overland wagons.
data.directionsInfo: Those portions of the California National Historic Trail authorized by Congress include nearly 2,000 miles of historic trail that was once the primary "road" taken by farmers, enterprising business managers, gold-seekers, and fortune hunters who chose to make a new life on the California frontier. The route passes through ten states from Missouri to California.

operatingHours.description: The California National Historic Trail is not a clearly marked hiking trail. Instead it is a corridor that passes through communities, urban areas, public lands, and Wilderness. The route travels across a variety of land ownerships and management, including private land. Each location varies as to the hours of operation and access. Please contact individual trail sites before your visit for more information.
operatingHours.name: California National Historic Trail

images.title: Wagon at Register Rock in City of Rocks National Reserve
images.altText: A white canvas wagon sits in front of a large rock buttress with mountains in the distance.
images.caption: Wagon at Register Rock in City of Rocks National Reserve

images.title: A creek in Carlin Canyon, Nevada on the California Trail
images.altText: A still creek winds through brown rolling hills.
images.caption: A creek in Carlin Canyon, Nevada on the California Trail

images.title: Trail ruts on through Humboldt Wells in Nevada
images.altText: A dirt road passes through sagebrush and a white post with a mountain in the background.
images.caption: Trail ruts on through Humboldt Wells in Nevada

images.title: Devil's Gate, Wyoming
images.altText: A rock buttress with a notch in it surrounded by sagebrush flats.
images.caption: Devil's Gate was an important emigrant landmark in Wyoming.

images.title: View of West Pass on Carson Route
images.altText: Pine trees partly obscure a distant mountain lake with snow-capped mountains.
images.caption: View of West Pass on the Carson Route of the California NHT.

data.weatherInfo: Due to the length of the California National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. Check out the forecast with the National Weather Service and search for the area you'd like to visit: weather.gov
data.name: California

multimedia.title: Alcove Spring – Place to visit on the Oregon & California national historic trails

data.description: The Homestead Act of 1862 transformed the world. Millions were invited to file claims including families, women, immigrants, and formerly enslaved people. Over 10 percent of the United States was homesteaded! The land, long inhabited by indigenous cultures, changed forever. Homesteaders created settlements and farms, drove industrial advancement, and built our nation chasing the American Dream.

emailAddresses.description: General mailbox for the public to contact the park.

data.directionsInfo: The park is 4 miles west of Beatrice on State Highway 4. From the U.S. 77 and U.S. 136 intersection in downtown Beatrice take U.S. 136 approximately 1.2 miles west. Turn right onto Nebraska Highway 4 and follow the signs. After the road has curved west and you have traveled 4 miles, you will enter Homestead National Historical Park and see signs for the different buildings at the park.

operatingHours.description: Trails and park grounds are open from sunrise to sunset. Picnic areas are available at the Education Center and Heritage Center. There are a total of 3.0 miles of trails through the tallgrass prairie and woodland.
operatingHours.name: Trails and Grounds

images.title: The Palmer Epard Cabin and the Heritage Center
images.altText: A historic cabin stands next to a concrete path that leads to a plow shaped visitor center
images.caption: The Palmer Epard Cabin and Heritage Center at Sunset

images.title: Freeman One-Room Schoolhouse
images.altText: A historic one room schoolhouse
images.caption: An original one-room schoolhouse, the Freeman School preserves educational history and allows for visitors of all ages to walk into history.

images.title: Grounds
images.altText: The tallgrass prairie is yellow with goldenrod in full bloom.
images.caption: The overlook from the picnic area at the Heritage Center showcases the beauty of the tallgrass prairie in late summer.

images.credit: Mel Mann, artist in residence of Homestead National Monument of America
images.title: Homestead Heritage Center
images.altText: The Homestead Heritage Center on the tallgrass prairie
images.caption: Thousands of visitors stop to view the oldest restored tallgrass prairie in the National Park Service from the Heritage Center back patio.

images.title: Grounds
images.altText: The tallgrass prairie spans to the Heritage Center on the horizon.
images.caption: The oldest restored tallgrass prairie in the NPS spans to the Heritage Center.

images.title: Homestead Education Center
images.altText: The Homestead Education Center
images.caption: The Homestead Education Center holds historic farm implements from the vast archives and collections of the Monument.

images.title: Palmer-Epard Homestead Cabin
images.altText: A homestead cabin at sunset
images.caption: The historic homestead cabin that can be found on the America the Beautiful Homestead Quarter, this cabin has been preserved in it's original condition for visitors to enter and see the inside of a historic structure.

data.weatherInfo: Homestead NHP's weather can vary quite a bit, even in a single day. In the summer, average daytime highs can exceed 80°F (27°C), only to drop 20 or more degrees when a thunderstorm rolls through. Winter lows fluctuate day to day and year to year, but average lows were measured at about 16°F (-9°C) for January and February over a 20-year period. Wind is common throughout the year.
data.name: Homestead

data.description: The Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail winds nearly 4,900 miles through the homelands of more than 60 Tribal nations. It follows the historic outbound and inbound routes of the Lewis and Clark Expedition of 1803-1806 from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania to the Pacific Ocean. Follow the trail to find the people, places, and stories that make up the complex legacy of the expedition.
data.directionsInfo: Lewis & Clark National Historic Trail Headquarters Visitor Center is located inside DOI, National Park Service, Interior Region 3,4,5 Office. We are right on the Missouri River next to the Bob Kerrey Pedestrian Bridge in downtown Omaha, NE.

operatingHours.description: Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center is located on the Missouri River in Omaha, Nebraska.
operatingHours.name: Visitor Center Hours

images.title: Giant Springs
images.altText: Small waterfall with brown rocks and green moss
images.caption: Giant springs is a site along the Lewis and Clark National Historic Site located in Great Falls, Montana

images.altText: sun dips behind mountains. In the foreground and meandering river catches the light. Leafy trees sur

images.caption: Cyclist along the riverfront along the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail

images.caption: Beacon Rock along the Columbia River in Washington.

data.weatherInfo: In winter, watch for ice on trails and sidewalks. In summer, make sure to drink plenty of water and wear sunscreen on hot days. Keep in mind the Trail covers 16 states, use www.weather.gov to look up the specific area you plan to visit.
data.name: Lewis & Clark

data.description: Imagine a 100-mile stretch of North America's longest river, a vestige of the untamed American West. The Missouri National Recreational River is where imagination meets reality. Two free flowing stretches of the Missouri make up the National Park. Relive the past by exploring the wild, untamed and mighty river that continues to flow as nature intended.
data.directionsInfo: The National Park Service headquarters is located at 508 East Second Street in Yankton, South Dakota.

operatingHours.description: The entire park includes the 39-Mile District and 59-Mile District. Both districts are open 24 hours, seven days a week.
operatingHours.name: Park Hours

images.title: Aerial of Missouri River
images.altText: Aerial view of the Missouri River and surrounding landscape.
images.caption: Aerial view of the Missouri River and surrounding landscape.

images.title: Remains of a sunken steamboat in Missouri River.
images.altText: Sunken remains of the North Alabama steamboat appears only when water is low.
images.caption: Sunken remains of the North Alabama steamboat appears only when water is low.

images.title: View of Missouri River
images.altText: Scenic view of Missouri River on a sunny day
images.caption: Scenic view of Missouri River on a sunny day

images.title: Park trailer
images.altText: Park educational trailer
images.caption: Educational trailer with painted pictures

images.title: All alone with my canoe
images.altText: A canoe loaded with gear sits quietly on a sandy river bank with blue sky above.
images.caption: Get into nature by paddling the Missouri River.

data.weatherInfo: Rapid weather changes are common along the Missouri National Recreational River corridor. Variations from season to season and from year to year are great. Characteristics of the climate are hot summers and cold winters. Sunshine is abundant, particularly in the summer months. Average annual rainfall is 25 inches. Thunderstorms can be dangerous and visitors should be prepared for them, especially from June until late August. Winter snowfall averages 34 inches annually.
data.name: Missouri

data.description: Explore the Mormon Pioneer National Historic Trail across five states to see the 1,300-mile route traveled by Mormons who fled Nauvoo, Illinois, to the Great Salt Lake Valley in 1846-1847.
data.directionsInfo: The Mormon Pioneer National Historic Trail crosses five states following the route the Pioneer Company of 1846-1847 established from Nauvoo, Illinois, to Salt Lake City, Utah, covering about 1,300 miles.

operatingHours.description: The Mormon Pioneer National Historic Trail is not a clearly marked hiking trail. Instead it is a corridor that passes through communities, urban areas, public lands, and Wilderness. The route travels across a variety of land ownerships and management, including private land. Each location varies as to the hours of operation and access. Please contact individual trail sites before your visit for more information.
operatingHours.name: Mormon Pioneer National Historic Trail

images.title: Echo Canyon, Utah
images.altText: Red cliffs line a highway as seen from a high point with grass in the foreground.
images.caption: Echo Canyon on the way from Wyoming to Salt Lake City, Utah is both beautiful and historic.

images.title: Brigham Young grave, Utah

images.caption: Brigham Young's grave lies in the heart of downtown Salt Lake City, Utah

images.caption: Monument Rock in Echo Canyon, Utah.

images.caption: Joseph & Emma Smith  House in Nauvoo, Illinois.

images.title: Mormon Pioneer Trail in Utah
images.altText: A hiking trail with a trail sign.
images.caption: There are places you can hike on the historic trail!

multimedia.title: Carthage Jail - Place to visit on the Mormon Pioneer National Historic Trail

data.description: With a little something for everyone, the Niobrara National Scenic River is a destination for crossing adventures off your bucket list. Most popular for river recreation, you can float the Niobrara River on a canoe, tube, or kayak as a beginner and have a blast. Hiking, biking, and wildlife watching keep our visitors busy. Oh! And we haven't even told you about the waterfalls yet.
data.directionsInfo: Most visitors start their trip in the city of Valentine, Nebraska. Valentine is 76 miles south of I-90 (Murdo, SD Exit) on Hwy 83; or 130 miles north of I-80 (North Platte, NE Exit) on Hwy 83. The nearest major airports are in Rapid City, SD (220 miles); Denver, CO (391 miles); and Omaha, NE (300 miles)

operatingHours.description: Most of the river itself is open 24 hours a day, with the exception of the river that flows through Fort Niobrara National Wildlife Refuge. The river in that stretch is open from sunrise to sunset. Please use caution: because the NPS does not own the land, different sites and private businesses have their own hours. Please ensure that you are following individual landowner regulations when you launch, take out, or visit individual areas.
operatingHours.name: Floating and paddling standard hours

images.title: Berry Falls along the Niobrara NSR.
images.altText: A beautiful, if short, waterfall empties into the side of the Niobrara NSR.
images.caption: Berry Falls is one of over 200 waterfalls that visitors may see along the Niobrara National Scenic River's bluffs.

images.title: Taking photos along the Niobrara NSR
images.altText: A man takes a photo of a meandering river from an overlook.
images.caption: Parts of the river are shallow and meandering, making beautiful backdrops for people to take photographs.

images.title: Fall colors along the Niobrara NSR
images.altText: Yellows, oranges, and greens dominate the fall colors along the Niobrara NSR.
images.caption: Autumn is a perfect time to enjoy the beauty of the Niobrara National Scenic River, from the river or the banks.

images.title: Canoeing the Niobrara NSR
images.altText: Two people in one canoe paddle along the bluffs of the Niobrara NSR.
images.caption: The Niobrara is a peaceful place to paddle during the week.

images.title: Relaxing canoeing on the Niobrara NSR
images.altText: A view from a canoe, with the photographer's feet resting on the bow, of the Niobrara NSR.
images.caption: Much of the Niobrara National Scenic River is easy paddling, suitable for novice canoers.

images.title: Egelhoffs Rapids on the Niobrara NSR
images.altText: A paddler in a canoe goes through Class II Rapids on the Niobrara NSR.
images.caption: An experienced canoer takes on the Class II Egelhoffs Rapids along the Niobrara National Scenic River.

images.title: Tubers congregate at Smith Falls State Park
images.altText: Many people on tubes float down the Niobrara.
images.caption: On Saturdays, the Niobrara National Scenic River is a great place to meet hundreds of other tubers.

data.weatherInfo: Summer (June-August): highs - low 80s to low 100s; lows - 50s to 60s, with occasional thunderstorms and associated strong winds. Moderate dry winds are common in the summer. 8.3" is average summer rainfall. Winter (November-April): Average highs 20-30s, average lows 0-10s with 5.5"/month average snowfall. Spring (April/May) and Fall (September/October) have cooler temperatures: average highs 60-70s, average lows 30-40s with 7.3" average rain/snowfall.
data.name: Niobrara

data.description: Imagine yourself an emigrant headed for Oregon: would promises of lush farmlands and a new beginning lure you to leave home and walk for weeks? More than 2,000 miles of trail ruts and traces can still be seen along the Oregon National Historic Trail in six states and serve as reminders of the sacrifices, struggles, and triumphs of early American settlers.
data.directionsInfo: More than 2,000 miles of trail ruts and traces can still be seen along the Oregon National Historic Trail in six states- reminders of the sacrifices, struggles, and triumphs of early American settlers.

operatingHours.description: The Oregon National Historic Trail is not a clearly marked hiking trail. Instead it is a corridor that passes through communities, urban areas, public lands and Wilderness. The route travels across a variety of land ownerships and management, including private land. Each location varies as to the hours of operation and access. Please contact trail sites before your visit for more information.
operatingHours.name: Oregon National Historic Trail

data.description: It is hard to believe that young men once rode horses to carry mail from Missouri to California in the unprecedented time of only 10 days. This relay system along the Pony Express National Historic Trail in eight states was the most direct and practical means of east-west communications before the telegraph.
data.directionsInfo: You can visit many sites of the Pony Express National Historic Trail over the 1,800-mile historic route that crosses 8 states.

operatingHours.description: The Pony Express National Historic Trail is not a clearly marked hiking trail. Instead it is a route that passes through communities, urban areas, public lands, and Wilderness. The route travels across a variety of land ownerships and management, including private land. Each location varies as to the hours of operations and access. Please contact individual trail sites before your visit for more information.
operatingHours.name: Pony Express National Historic Trail

data.description: Towering 800 feet above the North Platte River, Scotts Bluff has served as a landmark for peoples from Native Americans to emigrants on the Oregon, California and Mormon Trails to modern travelers. Rich with geological and paleontological history as well as human history, there is much to discover while exploring the 3,000 acres of Scotts Bluff National Monument.
data.directionsInfo: Visitors traveling east-west on Interstate 80 can exit at Kimball, Nebraska and drive 45 miles north on Nebraska Highway 71. Follow National Park Service signs three miles west of Gering, Nebraska to Old Oregon Trail Road. Turn west onto Old Oregon Trail Road and follow it approximately 2 miles to the monument visitor center on the right. Visitors travelling along the North Platte River using US Highway 26 or Nebraska Highway 92, should follow the National Park Service signs.

operatingHours.description: Scotts Bluff National Monument is located in the Mountain Time Zone. These hours are for the grounds, picnic area, and trails only. The hours for the Visitor Center and Summit Road are different. See below for Summit Road and Visitor Center hours.
operatingHours.name: Scotts Bluff National Monument

exceptions.name: Summit Road Fall/Winter/Spring Hours (early September though late May)

operatingHours.description: The Scotts Bluff Summit Road is a 1.6-mile drive to the summit of Scotts Bluff. Be aware that the road may close periodically due to weather conditions or rockslides. For the latest Summit Road conditions contact Scotts Bluff National Monument at (308) 436-9700. Entry by motorized vehicles during the fall/winter/spring seasons (September through late-May) is permitted from 9 a.m. until 4:00 p.m. Mountain Time.
operatingHours.name: Scotts Bluff Summit Road

images.title: Eagle Rock with Conestoga Wagon
images.altText: Conestoga wagon in front of Eagle Rock
images.caption: Thousands of covered wagons rolled by Eagle Rock in the mid nineteenth century.

images.title: Scotts Bluff from the North Platte RIver
images.altText: A pink sky and dramatic bluff are seen reflected in water.
images.caption: Scotts Bluff as seen from the north side of the North Platte River

images.title: A Hot Air Balloon at the East Entrance to the Monument
images.altText: A colorful hot air balloon is seen in the distance with the Scotts Bluff entrance sign.
images.caption: A hot air balloon is seen at the east entrance to Scotts Bluff National Monument.

images.title: Mitchell Pass bathed in Morning Light
images.altText: The distinctive rock formations of Mitchell Pass glow with early morning light.
images.caption: Early morning is a great time to explore Scotts Bluff National Monument.

images.title: Saddle Rock rises above the Clouds
images.altText: A unique rock formation is seen above a layer of clouds.
images.caption: An inversion creates the feeling of walking on the clouds at the summit of Scotts Bluff.

data.weatherInfo: Summers at Scotts Bluff are generally dry and high temperatures are usually in the 80's and 90's, although they can reach above 100 on occasion. Hikers are strongly advised to carry water. Winter daytime temperatures are usually in the 40's or low 50's, with overnight lows below freezing and, on occasion, below 0 degrees Fahrenheit. Although it can be windy any time of the year, spring is the windiest season.
data.name: Scotts Bluff
